Honestly bolu toh IOD is lowkey toxic af. Seniors bolte hai ragging nahi interaction hai but bhai same hi lagta hai. Power trip pura. Juniors ko neecha dikhana, dumb feel karwana, aur agar tum thoda sa bhi uncomfortable ho toh seedha bol dete design tumhare bas ka nahi hai. Wah.
Professors ka bhi alag scene. Favourites ko kuch bhi submit karne do, praise milta hai. Baaki log? Redo redo redo. Har cheez pe redo. Type redo, concept redo, mood hi pasand nahi aaya toh redo. Reason? Doesn‚Äôt feel right.Matlab kya.
Itna gaslight karte hai ki lagta hai problem hum hi hai. Thak jaate hai explain karte karte, improve karte karte. Design seekhne aaye the, anxiety mil rahi hai free mein. Har din lagta hai bas survive kar rahe hai.
Sab bolte hai this is design culture. Agar ye culture hai toh honestly bohot messed up hai

That guy was very‚Ä¶ quiet. The kind of quiet that makes you want to scream just to see if he‚Äôll blink. I started sitting two rows behind him in Macroeconomics just to watch the way he taps his pen when he‚Äôs stressed. It became a habit, then a ritual, then a haunting. I found his old social media‚Äîthe one he hasn't touched in years‚Äîand I spent all night scrolling back to who he was when he was sixteen. I feel like I own his past now. He‚Äôs so gentle when he talks to the barista, so oblivious to the way I‚Äôm vibrating with the need to just reach out and leave a mark on him. He‚Äôs the only thing that feels real in this empty place, and if I can't have him, I don't think I want anyone to have him.

Cse department ka ek teacher itna egoistic hai ki class mein thoda sa bhi late ho jaaye, toh marks ki automatically maa behen ek ho jaata hain. Aur mera toh luck bhi aisa hai ki woh sirf theory nahi, lab bhi handle karta hai. Matlab poora semester unke saale ego aur mood swings ke saaye mein rehna padta hai. Lab mein thoda sa experiment galat ya miss ho gaya, toh lecture mein bhi woh chutiya rant start kar deta hai. College aaya tha padhne, yahan toh bas yeh saala drama aur unlucky combination mein marks ke liye struggle karna pad raha hai ü§°

But honestly‚Ä¶ sab bakwaas hai. Yeh banda lowkey chutiya nikla.

Mujhe doubt hua toh thoda idhar-udhar pucha and surprise surprise yeh madarchod same drama bohot logon ke saath kar raha hai.

Ab toh banda ekdum red flag on legs lag raha hai.

I‚Äôve been wanting to say this since a few weeks but samajh hi nahi aa raha tha kaise start karu.
‚Ä®I‚Äôm from FY and honestly, college ke first few months sabko exciting lagte hain, but mere liye thode scary ho gaye. Ghar se itna pressure hai ki kabhi kabhi lagta hai saans lene ka bhi permission chahiye.

Maine ye course khud choose nahi kiya. Bas bola gaya ‚Äúye better hai, scope hai, kar lo.‚Äù Maine bhi haan bol diya kyunki argue karne ki himmat nahi thi. Sabko lagta hai main chill hoon, but andar se main constantly stressed rehta hoon.

Aur phir ek din‚Ä¶‚Ä®ek chhoti si cheez ho gayi jo mere liye bohot badi ban gayi.

I didn‚Äôt do well in one internal. Zyada bada fail nahi tha, but mere liye kaafi tha panic karne ke liye. Abhi tak ghar pe nahi bataya. Har call pe poochte hain ‚Äúsab theek chal raha hai na?‚Äù aur main bol deta hoon ‚Äúhaan haan, mast.‚Äù

Sach ye hai ki mujhe darr lagta hai.‚Ä®Darr lagta hai ki agar sach bola toh disappointment dikhegi. Darr lagta hai ki agar main thak gaya toh koi samjhega bhi ya nahi. Kabhi kabhi lagta hai main bas expectations carry kar raha hoon, apni life nahi jee raha.

What was the sluttiest moment of your college life?

When I was 19, I lost myself. I was extremely promiscuous and looked for love in people who were: popular, stand-offish, narcissistic. I met a group of popular guys in college. Some were musicians, some were basketball players, some were ‚Äòmodels‚Äô. I will admit, that most of the men were Black. Not that this matters to me, I always found Black men attractive. I did sleep with white guys too, but I‚Äôll be honest - I think it was exciting for me at the time and it seemed to me that black men saw in me what white guys didnt - I was curvier than most of my friends and had thick, curly, Afro like hair. I never thought of any consequences. I craved the attention of people who were loved by others, because I wanted to be loved. As a teen I shyed away from sex, but during this time it meant NOTHING to me. It was just a tool I used to be the centre of a mans attention. Yes, I had ‚Äòdaddy issues‚Äô. I was searching for something. Love?

I‚Äôm 25 now. I‚Äôve been in a relationship for three years and my partner is aware of some of the circumstances, although I haven‚Äôt told him everything. I‚Äôm no longer promiscuous and am in therapy - I also meditate and take yoga classes. I feel like the same person I was when I was 16 (before I lost myself), only now I love myself.

My boyfriend is creative. He writes music, has a clothing line and is interested in building further businesses. He is also Black. I love his soul and we connect on a deep level. He says he does not want to be famous, but I‚Äôm terrified that this is where his career is leading. If he does become famous, rumours would probably start to pour out about me.

Can anyone offer support or guidance? I feel ashamed, scared and like I‚Äôm losing myself again. I‚Äôm doing everything I can to retain balance. Also, the fact that these men were black means nothing to me, I‚Äôve slept with Asian guys, just as many white guys too. But, you know what society says about white women who sleep with a stereotype - take Kim Kardashian for example.

I saw her first time in canteen, second year. She was always with her gang, laughing loud, acting like she doesn‚Äôt care about anyone. I noticed her way before she noticed me.
Months went like that. Small small things only. She sat few tables away. Once she asked for my charger. Said ‚Äúthanks yaar‚Äù and left. For her it was normal. For me, whole day mood set.
One day we actually talked. Random bakwas like attendance, exams, how college is trash. She said I‚Äôm ‚Äútoo seedha‚Äù for this college. I laughed, but inside my heart was racing.
That night she replied to my story. Just one word ‚Äî cute.‚Ä®We talked till 2 AM. No flirting, just vibes.
Then she asked, ‚ÄúHave you ever liked someone from college?‚Äù
I typed haan.‚Ä®She asked, ‚ÄúWho?‚Äù
I was still typing‚Ä¶‚Ä®then she sent, ‚ÄúChhod, I shouldn‚Äôt ask.‚Äù
I never sent the message.

Next day in college, everything felt same but also not. She saw me, smiled little, then went back to her friends. No awkwardness. No questions.
I kept thinking maybe she knows. Maybe she guessed.‚Ä®But she never asked again.
We still talk sometimes. Notes, exams, memes. Late replies now. Earlier it was instant.‚Ä®She watches my stories within minutes. Never replies.
Once I almost told her. My finger was on send.‚Ä®Then I remembered how easily she said ‚Äúchhod‚Äù that night.
So I didn‚Äôt.
Maybe she was just curious.‚Ä®Maybe she felt something too and got scared.‚Ä®Or maybe I imagined everything because I wanted it to be true.
We sit in same canteen. Same college. Same life.‚Ä®But that message is still unsent.
And I don‚Äôt know if keeping quiet saved our friendship‚Ä¶‚Ä®or killed something before it even started.

I saw him first in my SY sitting in the IT library. I liked him quietly for six months - stolen glances in between classes, accidental eye contact that never lasted more than a second. When I finally confessed, he came to my Python lab even though he didn‚Äôt have to. Sat next to me. Smiled. Blushed. Moved closer. Our legs touched and neither of us pulled away.

He asked why I liked him for so long. Said he wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äúgood boy.‚Äù Mentioned things that should‚Äôve scared me - but didn‚Äôt. When I teased him with his ring, he let me keep it. When I complimented him, he hid his smile like it meant too much.

I asked if I could hold his hand. He hesitated‚Ä¶ then gave it to me anyway.

Then he leaned in and asked,
‚ÄúSo what exactly do you want from me?‚Äù
I never answered.
And that‚Äôs where everything changed.

I smiled and told him I didn‚Äôt know, because I was scared of hearing his answer first. He laughed like he understood more than he let on. Said if he didn‚Äôt care, he wouldn‚Äôt be sitting there, in my lab , holding my hand under a desk with cameras watching.

He asked to hang out sometime. I said not yet. He nodded, didn‚Äôt push.
Before leaving, he told me not to overthink then disappeared into his own world.
That night, he sent one message. A heart reaction. Nothing more.

Seven days later, he still watches me from a distance, my stories, my silences but never steps closer.

And I‚Äôm left wondering, was that the beginning of something‚Ä¶‚Ä®or the moment it quietly ended?

After diploma, I transferred to sy and quickly became acquainted with the neighbour in my dorm, a girl who was a design student. She lived in a 1rk. Despite the rumors circulating among the guys about her offering handjobs for 500 & bj for 3k, I initially ignored them. 

She seemed dedicated to her studies, often found in the library, and didn't socialize much, which didn't fit the stereotype of someone engaging in such activities. However, as the semester progressed, I started to notice that guys frequently visited her room, which piqued my curiosity.

It was the last week of the sem-4, and with  upcoming OS exam, I was feeling the stress. One of my stress reactions is becoming quite horny. The rumors about the her kept playing in my mind, so I decided to test their validity. I then made up a question about OS and knocked on her door. After she explained it, she asked if there was anything else I needed. When she said, "Anything at all?" I hesitated, but she seemed to understand my hesitation. "You brought money?" she asked, and I nodded. She tapped her desk, and I laid the money out so she could count it. I sat in her chair, and she removed her tshirt. The rumors were true. She used tissues to cover the head of my cock when I finished. What started as a one-time thing turned into a recurring scenario, with me visiting her about four times in last 3 months.

I want to share something that happened in my college a while back. I‚Äôm not mentioning the name of the institution, but I still can‚Äôt forget something that happened last year when I was a fresher. I won‚Äôt name the college, but it‚Äôs a very reputed institution where most students are JEE Advanced qualified so naturally, people expect discipline, maturity, and a higher standard of behavior.

Our college is known to be strict about ragging. Because of repeated past issues (mostly involving boys), the anti-ragging monitoring period was extended from 28 days to 4 months. Even then, things went wrong.

This time, it wasn‚Äôt the boys it was senior girls. Many freshers, especially girls, refused to address seniors as ma‚Äôam or sir (which is actually a rule here). The seniors felt disrespected. To make things worse, some senior boys were giving a lot of attention to just a few freshers, which created jealousy and ego clashes among the senior girls.

Once the official anti-ragging period ended, a group of senior girls called the fresher girls into the bathroom (since there were no CCTVs) and forced them into humiliating acts. They made them dance on the commode and bring food from the night canteen. one of my friends, who was close with the seniors, was actually the one sharing the freshers‚Äô numbers.

The juniors were devastated. Many cried a lot, and the case eventually reached the higher authorities. Some seniors were about to be debarred for 28 days, but certain professors stepped in and prevented strict punishment. After this, the fresher girls‚Äô group completely broke apart, and their mental health was badly affected.

It‚Äôs been a year, but this incident still stays in my mind. At first, I thought ragging was just a tradition or a bonding exercise, but witnessing this changed my perspective. Even in a place filled with JEE Advanced qualified students, ego and power games can create lasting scars.

It‚Äôs funny how people talk about ‚Äúvibes‚Äù and ‚Äúpositivity‚Äù but back-bitching starts the moment someone leaves the room. College ne ek cheez sikhayi smile doesn‚Äôt always mean respect.

I don‚Äôt know when it started, but ab college aana sirf lectures ke liye nahi hota. Tumhari ek glimpse mil jaaye din ban jaata hai. We‚Äôve never really talked properly, but somehow you‚Äôre a part of my daily routine  Weird hai, but true.
Some people act like they‚Äôre everyone‚Äôs friend, but privately unka favourite hobby dusron ke secrets share karna hota hai. Trust carefully, guys.

I never thought Design Building ke bahar khade hoke kisi ka wait karna meri daily habit ban jaayega. Tum tuck shop se kuch lene jaate ho aur main bas pretend karta hoon ki casually phone scroll kar raha hoon. Truth is, tumhari ek glimpse mil jaaye toh pura din thoda better lagta hai.

don‚Äôt know when you became such a big part of my college life. Kabhi Raj Mess ke bahar line mein khade hote hue, kabhi SOC building ke stairs pe tumhe haste hue dekh leta hoon bas wahi moment poora din set kar deta hai. We don‚Äôt talk much, but somehow you‚Äôre always there in my head. College aaye the degree ke liye, par tum mil gaye‚Ä¶ syllabus se zyada confusing ho gaya sab.

I think you‚Äôre the president of some business club‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not even sure which one, but the way people listen when you speak makes it obvious. I really like you, even though we‚Äôve never properly talked. Maybe you‚Äôll never read this, but if you do 
just know someone admires you quietly from the crowd.
